Paper Ko*139-A - already circulated).Minutes of the Committee of Imperial Defence,(C,I.D,/203rd Meeting p.p.,9-12 - already circulated).Memorandum by Lord Balfour,(CP. 437 (25) - already circulated).2S I3ISH BOUNDARY COM-.: IBS ION - REPORT.(Reference Cabinet 50 (25) Conclusion 6 -(e) )*(S signed ) M.P.A . HAN KEY,Secretary, Cabinet.Whitehall Gardens, S .V/. 1.26th October, 1925. f^rffTH^SQCmi^lT IS THE PROPERTY OP HIS BRITANNIC MAJE STYTS GOVERNMENT)s^cj e t.COPY MOjCABINET 51(25).CONCLUSIONS of a Meeting- of the Cabinet heldat 10., Downing Street, S.WaX., on WEDNESDAY,October 28th, 1925, at 11.30 A.M.PRESENT;-The Right Hon. Stanley Baldwin, M.P.,Prime Minister.Right Hon.Viscount Gave, G.C.M.G..ford Chancellor.'-Right Hon.W.S. Churchill, C.H..M.P.,Chancellor of the Exchequer.i Right Bon.L.S. Amery., M.P., secretary of State for Dominion affairs and Secretary of State forthe Colonies.J Sight Hon.W..G. Bridgeman, M.P.,First lord of the Admiralty.3 Right Hon.Neville Chamberlain, M.P.,Minister of Health.a Right Hon.lord Eustaoe erey, M.P.,President of the Board of \.-.Education.e Bight Bon.Viscount Peel, G.B.B., first commissioner of Works.(In the Chair).The Most Hon..The Marquess of Salisbury,K.G. ,C.C V.O. ,CB.,Lord Privy Seal.The Right Hon.Sir William Joynson-Hicks,Bart.,M.P., Seoretary ofState for Home Affairs.The Right Hon.Sir Laming Worthington-Evens,Bart ...G.3.E. .M.P., secretary of State for War.The Right Hon.Sir Samuel Hoare, Bart..C.M.G.,M.P., Seoretary ofState for Air.The Right Hon.Sir Philip Cunliffo-Lister,K.3.B. ,M.C..,M.P., Presidentof the Board of Trade.The Right Hon.Sir John Gi&mour, Bart..D.S.O..M.P., Secretary for Scotland.The Right Hon.Sir Arthur Steel-Maitland,Bart.M.P.. Minister of Labour.The Right Hon.Sir Douglas Hogg, K.C. .M.P.,Attorney-General.i^A. Hankey, G.C.B.....................,.......Secretary. parliamentary business.The MiningSubsidy.(previous reference!Cabinet 50(85), Con-oluaion 6.)1* The Chancellor of the Exchequer informed theCabinet that, according to the estimates of the mines Depar+ment, which, however, the treasury had not yet discussed in detail with that department the amount of the Mining Subsidy necessitated upto the end-of March would be 17,000,000, whichwas a considerable advance on previous estimates.This would involve a Vote in Parliament before christmas, the discussion of whioh might requireas much as two days.NorthernIrelandInsuranceBill.(previous reference e:Cabinet 50(25), Con-clusion 6.)Towards the end of the Meeting the Chancellorof the Exchequer reported that It was not essentialthat the Northern Ireland Insurance Bill (a draftof which was handed round) should be passed before christmas, but it was essential that it should be passed into law before March, 1926.Re pre sent a-tion of thePeople (EconomyPrivieions)Bill.(previous reference:Cabinet 50(25), Con-conclusion 6.)In view of the above, the Cabinet agreed --That it would be advisable, ifpossible, to. secure the passageof the Representation of thePeople (Economy Provisions) bill before Christmasif this couldbe arranged. B. The Cabinet had before than: the following papers in connection with the reduction of Rosythand"Pembroke DockyardsA Letter and Memorandum circiliated bythe First Lord of the Admiralty(Paper C.P.-422 (25)).A Letter from the Admiralty to theCommittee of Imperial Defence,together with a Memorandum on the strategical Aspects of the question(CI.D, Paper No.l39-A).An Extract from the Minutes of the203rd Meeting of the Committee ofImperial Defence held on October15th, 1925.A Memorandum by the Lord Presidentof the Council (The Earl of Balfour)(Paper CP.-437 (25)) .The Prime Minister stated that he had felt obliged to Inform the Deputations from Pembroke andRosyth. that, if the decision to reduce Rosyth andPembroke Dockyards was adhered to, the Governmentwould not oppose a Parliamentary Debate on the subjectif this were asked for.The First Lord of the Admiralty intimated thatsome mitigation of the hardships resulting from the closing Of these Dockyards might arise from ship-breaking at both places: by proceeding with, theAdmiralty oil installation at Pembroke; and by keeping in the care-and-maintenance parties at the Dockyardsthose who had purchased their houses.A-fter considerable discussion, the cabinet agreed -That, with a view to a decision attheir next Meeting, the Chancellorof the Exchequer, m consultationwith the First Lord of the admiralty and the Secretary for Scotland, andany other Minister who might be concerned, sho\xld present, theCabinet with a comprehensive state-rrent of the total saving which was estimated to result from the closing of Rosyth and Pembroke Dockyards when,against the saving on Adm.admiralty Votes,was set the increases on other Votes,such as the"cost of the.guarantee to-2- the Scottish National HousingCompany (by the Scottish Ministryof Health) in respect of houses built for Rosyth workers; anycorresponding losses at Pembroke;,losses due to extra housing thatwould have to be provided at portsmouth, Plymouth and Chatham:loss due to Unemployment. Benefitat places where the general em-ploy." ent of the community was dependent on Dockyards, etc. 3. The Cabinet had before them a Memorandum bythe Secretaries of State for the Home Depart:entand for Dominion Affairs in regard to arrangementsfor giving effect to the Award of the Irish boundary commission whenever that ward is giver? (Paper C.P.-445 (25)) .The Conclusion on this subject will be circulatedlater, THE GRAB CO-BULGARIANFRONTIER.(previousRefers no e:nabinet 50(85), Con-oluslen 2.)4. During the Meeting the Cabinet received and considered, 83 a matter of urgency, the first partof a message from the Secretary of State for ForeignAffairs (lord Crewe'a telegram from Parie No .377,of October 27th) in which Mr Chamberlain expressed his intention of supporting a proposal that ifGreece refused to desist from military operations and to withdraw her troops, the Council of theLeague should recommend (a) The immediate withdrawal of theChief3 of Missions, to be followed.If Greece continues recalcitrant, by(b) A naval demonstration at Piraeuswith the briefest possible delay,''The Cabinet agreed That the Prime Minister should inform the Secretary of State for ,-Foreign Affaire that they agreed in his proposal but of course onthe assumption that any demonstra-tion against Greece would be ajoint one.* , * 4I &. Whitehall Oardene, S.W.1,October 28, 1925,
